bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 20, 1890

div1.p: Lazear gives his impressions of Glasgow. After a brief return to Edinburgh, he travels to London.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 20, 1890
div1.p:
I am back again in Edinburgh.
I reached here from Glasgow a little before
ten last night and came at once to
Mrs Magills and I am now in my old
room. My plan was to take an
excursion to Dundee to-day, but I
found that I had a great many
things to do and I am a little tired
of sight seeing anyhow, so I gave
up the trip. I reached Glasgow
yesterday about noon and went
to the Post Office at once and mailed
a letter to you. Then I went with
Norris and Knapp and took lunch
and afterward visited the University
of Glasgow and went to the Heniterian
Museum of Anatomy which is in one
of the P buildings of the University.
The university buildings are very fine.
We also went to the cathedral which
is one of the sights of the place.
Yesterday happened to be Glasgow Train
day which is one of the old local
holidays. We went out to Whitevale
where the people were having their
so-called fun. It was the oddest
sight I ever saw. There was an
enclosure full of merry-go-rounds
swings and shows of all kinds
and packed with people mostly
drunk. There were at least twenty
five merry-go-rounds. They each had
an orchestrian and every now and
then they blew steam whistles to
attract attention. These things have
not only the circular motion but
also an up and down motion.

Then there was a long string of little shows
which gave performances lasting about
half an hour charging a penny or two.
Between each performance the company
came out on a kind of balcony and
gave a sample of their performance
before the crowd, meanwhile an orchestrian
played, the managers howled swung rattles
blew horns and made every possible noise
to attract attention to their own shows.
The whole thing made a din that was
indiscribable. I wanted to see Glasgow
in its every day garb as it is said to be
a very busy bustling city but I had to
make the best of it as I found it. I had
never given Glasgow credit for being so
large a city as it is. Its population is 750,000
and it is the second city in Great Britain.
It is larger than Liverpool and three
twice times as large as Edinburgh.
I will leave early tomorrow for
London.

2 Queens Square Place
Queens Square
Bloomsburg
London, W.C.

The above is the situation of my London
lodgings. I reached here on Monday night
and stayed that night at the Midland
Grand Hotel. Yesterday morning I started
out in search of lodgings and finally hit upon
this place. It is on a little offset from
Queens Square and is as quiet as the
country, and is very cheap. I get the
room for eight shillings a week and
the landlady gives me breakfast charging
me just for what I eat. I get lunch
and dinner elsewhere. This is a better
plan than boarding, as it would be
impossible to come home to all meals.
I am afraid that this letter will
miss the boat. I thought it sailed
on Thursday but I find it is today.
However I will close and hurry
and mail it in the hope that it
will go. I will write more about
London next week letter
